message_1:
What is the enthalpy change of reduction for the following reaction at 298 K:
Fe2O3(s) + 3CO(g) -> 2Fe(s) + 3CO2(g)
Given:
- Enthalpy of formation of Fe2O3(s) = -824 kJ/mol
- Enthalpy of formation of CO2(g) = -393.5 kJ/mol
- Standard enthalpy of formation of CO(g) = -110.5 kJ/mol
- Standard molar entropies at 298K:
Fe2O3(s) = 87.4 J/K/mol
CO(g) = 197.7 J/K/mol
CO2(g) = 213.6 J/K/mol
message_2:
To calculate the enthalpy change of reduction for the given reaction, we can use the following formula:

ΔH_reaction = Σ ΔH_f(products) - Σ ΔH_f(reactants)

where ΔH_f is the standard enthalpy of formation.

For the given reaction:

ΔH_reaction = [2ΔH_f(Fe) + 3ΔH_f(CO2)] - [ΔH_f(Fe2O3) + 3ΔH_f(CO)]

Since the standard enthalpy of formation for elements in their standard state (such as Fe) is zero, we can simplify the equation:

ΔH_reaction = [3ΔH_f(CO2)] - [ΔH_f(Fe2O3) + 3ΔH_f(CO)]

Now, we can plug in the given values:

ΔH_reaction = [3(-393.5 kJ/mol)] - [(-824 kJ/mol) + 3(-110.5 kJ/mol)]

ΔH_reaction = [-1180.5 kJ/mol] - [-1155.5 kJ/mol]

ΔH_reaction = -25 kJ/mol

So, the enthalpy change of reduction for the given reaction at 298 K is -25 kJ/mol.
